quickScenarioChallenge.challengeSubtitle: Don't worry if you get it wrong‚Äîthat's how you learn!
quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: You're leading a software development project. The sponsor wants to skip stakeholder meetings to save time and just implement what they originally requested. The team suggests iterative development with frequent reviews, but the sponsor insists on a fixed plan. Team morale is dropping because they feel micromanaged and not trusted to make decisions.
quickScenarioChallenge.question: FIRST

options.A: Follow the sponsor's wishes since they're funding the project
options.B: Advocate for stakeholder engagement, adaptive approaches, and team empowerment
options.C: Create a detailed plan and stick to it to avoid scope creep
options.D: Let the team work however they want without oversight

ahaDebrief.correctAnswer: B - Advocate for stakeholder engagement, adaptive approaches, and team empowerment

coreFramework.frameworkName: CLIMB HIGHER Framework - The 12 PM Principles
coreFramework.frameworkIntro: You just experienced multiple principles in action. Now here's the complete framework PMI expects you to know:

rows.action: Demonstrate leadership behaviors that serve the team
rows.examKeywords: servant leader, support team, remove blockers

rows.action: See the project as part of a larger system
keyQuestions: How does this impact the organization?

rows.action: Navigate complexity, not just follow a plan
Act responsibly inside and outside the organization
keyQuestions: Am I serving the greater good?

rows.action: Tailor approach to fit the project context
Build quality into processes and deliverables
Enable change to achieve the envisioned future
keyQuestions: How do we embrace this change?

rows.action: Trust team to make decisions and self-organize

secondScenario.title: Apply the CLIMB HIGHER Framework
secondScenario.intro: Now that you know the framework, let's apply it to a new situation.
secondScenario.scenarioStory: Your project is facing significant technical complexity. The team is struggling, but they're afraid to admit they need help. The sponsor is pressuring for faster delivery. You notice quality is slipping.
secondScenario.question: What principles should guide your FIRST action?

options.A: Generate Value - Push for faster delivery to satisfy the sponsor
options.B: Lead with Servant Leadership - Support the team, address complexity, incorporate quality
options.C: Be a Steward - Report the team's struggles to senior management
options.D: Empower the Team - Let them figure it out on their own

quotes.text: The principles are the fundamental norms, rules, or values that represent what is desirable and best for the organization and project. They are not a checklist; they interact and depend on each other.
quotes.author: PMI

quotes.text: The exam tests whether you understand WHY these principles matter. Don't just memorize them‚Äîunderstand how they guide decisions. When two principles seem to conflict, the answer is usually about balance.
quotes.author: PMP Instructor Insight

fieldInsights.title: Real-World Application
fieldInsights.insight: Experienced PMs know that principles aren't rigid rules. They're guideposts. When a sponsor demands something unethical (violating Stewardship), you advocate for what's right. When complexity increases (Manage Complexity), you don't panic‚Äîyou adapt your approach.

fieldInsights.title: Exam Strategy
fieldInsights.insight: On the exam, look for answers that demonstrate MULTIPLE principles working together. The best answer usually involves collaboration, value delivery, and team empowerment.

memoryPalace.title: üèîÔ∏è Memory Palace: Climbing the Mountain
memoryPalace.intro: Anchor the 12 principles with this vivid mountain climbing story. As you read, visualize each scene:

story.title: The Summit Quest Expedition
story.narrative: You're leading an expedition to climb a challenging mountain. Your team of 12 climbers represents the 12 principles.

scenes.description: At base camp, everyone gathers around the campfire. The team collaborates on the route plan, sharing ideas and building trust. Collaboration is where it all begins.
The lead climber goes first, setting ropes and clearing obstacles for others. True leaders serve by removing impediments.
At a junction, you study the map showing how your route connects to the larger mountain system. Everything is interconnected.
You navigate through a complex ice maze. You can't eliminate it, but you can navigate through it carefully.
A guardian protects an old bridge, ensuring it's used responsibly. Stewardship means protecting resources and acting ethically.
Each climber adjusts their harness to fit perfectly. Tailoring means customizing your approach.
Before the summit push, you inspect every piece of gear. Quality is built in, not inspected in later.
The golden flag at the summit represents the value you're delivering. Every step brings you closer to that goal.
Sudden winds change conditions. You adapt your route instead of stubbornly continuing. Honor change by being flexible.
You trust each climber to choose their own hand-holds and make route micro-decisions. Empowerment means trust.
Throughout the climb, you constantly scan for rockfall hazards and avalanche risk. Risk management never stops.

story.moral: You successfully summit because you applied all 12 principles throughout the journey. Each principle supported the others, and together they led to success.

memoryPalace.selfTest: Close your eyes and walk through the mountain climb. Can you recall all 12 principles from CLIMB HIGHER using the story?
